Identification.LongTitle: Export of Substances on the Export Control List Regulations

Provision.Text: Whereas, pursuant to subsection 332(1)a of the Canadian Environmental Protection Act, 1999b, the Minister of the Environment published in the Canada Gazette, Part I, on August 6, 2011, a copy of the proposed Export of Substances on the Export Control List Regulations, substantially in the annexed form, and persons were given an opportunity to file comments with respect to the Regulations or to file a notice of objection requesting that a board of review be established and stating the reasons for the objection;

Therefore, His Excellency the Governor General in Council, on the recommendation of the Minister of the Environment and the Minister of Health, pursuant to subsection 102(1) of the Canadian Environmental Protection Act, 1999b, makes the annexed Export of Substances on the Export Control List Regulations.

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in these Regulations.

Definition.Text: Act means the Canadian Environmental Protection Act, 1999. (Loi)
CAS registry number means the identification number assigned to a chemical substance by the Chemical Abstracts Service Division of the American Chemical Society. (numéro d’enregistrement CAS)

designated national authority means an authority designated by a Rotterdam Party under Article 4 of the Rotterdam Convention to act on its behalf in the performance of the administrative functions required by the Rotterdam Convention. (autorité nationale désignée)
Export Control List means the Export Control List in Schedule 3 to the Act. (Liste des substances d’exportation contrôlée)
Minamata Convention means the Minamata Convention on Mercury, as amended from time to time. (Convention de Minamata)
pesticide means a pest control product as defined in subsection 2(1) of the Pest Control Products Act. (produit antiparasitaire)

PIC Circular means the circular that is published by the Rotterdam Secretariat and that contains a compilation of import responses from Rotterdam Parties, provided in accordance with Article 10 of the Rotterdam Convention, and a list of the substances subject to the prior informed consent procedure. (Circulaire PIC)

Rotterdam Convention means the Rotterdam Convention on the Prior Informed Consent Procedure for Certain Hazardous Chemicals and Pesticides in International Trade, as amended from time to time. (Convention de Rotterdam)
Rotterdam Party means a State or regional economic integration organization for which the Rotterdam Convention is in force. (Partie à la Convention de Rotterdam)
Rotterdam Secretariat means the Secretariat for the Rotterdam Convention established under Article 19 of that Convention. (Secrétariat de Rotterdam)
Stockholm Convention means the Stockholm Convention on Persistent Organic Pollutants, as amended from time to time. (Convention de Stockholm)
Stockholm Party means a State or regional economic integration organization for which the Stockholm Convention is in force. (Partie à la Convention de Stockholm)

substance subject to the prior informed consent procedure means a substance specified in Annex III of the Rotterdam Convention that is destined for use in the category specified in that Annex. (substance soumise à la procédure de consentement préalable)

Section.Text: The purpose of these Regulations is to establish regulatory conditions applicable to the export of substances specified in the Export Control List and to implement the Stockholm Convention, Rotterdam Convention and Minamata Convention in relation to the export of those substances.

Subsection.Text: These Regulations set out the content of the notice of proposed export that is required under subsection 101(1) of the Act for substances specified in Schedule 3 to the Act, and the period within which and manner in which the notice must be provided.
These Regulations also set out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for the purposes of subsection 101(3) of the Act, the conditions applicable to the export of a substance that is specified in Part 2 or 3 of Schedule 3 to the Act and that is also targeted by the Stockholm Convention or the Minamata Convention; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for the purposes of subsections 101(2) and (3) of the Act, the conditions applicable to the export of a substance that is specified in Schedule 3 to the Act to a Rotterdam Party, including permit, liability insurance and labelling requirements.

Section.Text: These Regulations apply to the export of substances specified in the Export Control List.

Subsection.Text: The notice of proposed export that is required under subsection 101(1) of the Act must be provided to the Minister by the person proposing the export of a substance at least

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the person holds a permit to export the substance issued under paragraph 185(1)(b) of the Act or under the Ozone-depleting Substances and Halocarbon Alternatives Regulations, seven days before the export; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any other case, 15 days before the export.

Subsection.Text: The notice is considered to be provided to the Minister

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on the day on which it is delivered, if it is delivered personally;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on the day on which it is postmarked, if it is sent by mail; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: on the date that is indicated by the sending apparatus, if it is sent by electronic mail or by facsimile.

Subsection.Text: The notice of proposed export must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: provide the information set out in Schedule 1; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be accompanied by a certification, dated and signed by the person proposing the export, or by their duly authorized representative, stating that the information provided in the notice is accurate and complete.

Subsection.Text: The notice of proposed export and the certification may be submitted either in writing or in an electronic format that is compatible with the one that is used by the Minister and the documents must bear the signature of the person proposing the export or their duly authorized representative.
The exporter must notify the Minister in writing of any change to the information provided in a notice of proposed export within 30 days after learning of it.

Heading.TitleText: Conditions Relative to the Stockholm Convention

Subsection.Text: In this section, persistent organic pollutant means a substance listed in Annex A or B of the Stockholm Convention, other than one added to that Convention by an amendment that is not in force for Canada.

Subsection.MarginalNote: POP specified in Part 2 or 3 of Schedule 3 to Act
Subsection.Text: A person that has provided a notice of proposed export under subsection 101(1) of the Act may export a persistent organic pollutant that is specified in Part 2 or 3 of the Export Control List under the following conditions, unless the export of that persistent organic pollutant is prohibited by any other regulation made under the Act:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if a specific exemption or acceptable purpose is listed in Annex A or B of the Stockholm Convention for that persistent organic pollutant and the export is to a Stockholm Party,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: that Party has registered a specific exemption or acceptable purpose in the relevant Register established under the Stockholm Convention and the export complies with the terms of that specific exemption or acceptable purpose,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of a persistent organic pollutant added to the Stockholm Convention by an amendment that is not in force for that Party, an annual certification for the year in question regarding that Party that is in accordance with paragraph 2 (b) (iii) of Article 3 of the Stockholm Convention has been transmitted by Canada to the Secretariat established under that Convention, and the export complies with the terms of the specific exemption or acceptable purpose listed in those Annexes;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if a specific exemption or acceptable purpose is listed in Annex A or B of the Stockholm Convention for that persistent organic pollutant and the export is to a State or regional economic integration organization that is not a party to the Stockholm Convention, an annual certification for the year in question regarding that State or organization that is in accordance with paragraph 2 (b) (iii) of Article 3 of the Stockholm Convention has been transmitted by Canada to the Secretariat established under that Convention, and the export complies with the terms of the specific exemption or acceptable purpose listed in those Annexes;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the persistent organic pollutant is exported in accordance with paragraph 1 (d) of Article 6 of the Stockholm Convention;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the persistent organic pollutant is exported for use in a laboratory for analysis, in scientific research or as a laboratory analytical standard and the total quantity exported by the person during the calendar year in question does not exceed 10 kg;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the persistent organic pollutant is incidentally present in trace amounts in the product that is being exported; or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the persistent organic pollutant is contained in a product

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: that was manufactured on or before the entry into force for Canada of a provision of the Stockholm Convention prohibiting, under Annex A, or restricting, under Annex B, the production or use of that persistent organic pollutant, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in respect of which a notification has been provided by Canada in accordance with note (ii) to Annex A or B of the Stockholm Convention and the notification has been made publicly available in accordance with that note by the Secretariat established under the terms of that Convention.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (2) does not apply to a persistent organic pollutant that is, or is contained in, a hazardous waste or hazardous recyclable material regulated by the Export and Import of Hazardous Waste and Hazardous Recyclable Material Regulations.

Heading.TitleText: Conditions Relative to the Rotterdam Convention

Subsection.Text: Subject to section 23, sections 8 to 22 set out the additional conditions applicable to the export of a substance specified in the Export Control List if that export is to a Rotterdam Party.
Sections 8 to 22 do not apply to a substance that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is contained in a manufactured item that during manufacture is formed into a specific physical shape or design and has for its final use a function or functions wholly or partly dependent on its shape or design;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is, or is contained in, a hazardous waste or hazardous recyclable material regulated by the Export and Import of Hazardous Waste and Hazardous Recyclable Material Regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is, or is contained in, a controlled substance as defined in subsection 2(1) of the Controlled Drugs and Substances Act;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: is, or is contained in, a nuclear substance as defined in section 2 of the Nuclear Safety and Control Act;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: is, or is contained in, a chemical weapon as defined by the Convention on the Prohibition of the Development, Production, Stockpiling and Use of Chemical Weapons and on Their Destruction, signed at Paris, France, on January 13, 1993, as amended from time to time;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: is, or is contained in, a food or drug as defined in section 2 of the Food and Drugs Act or a food additive as defined in Part B of the Food and Drug Regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: is contained in a product at a concentration of less than 0.1% by weight;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: is exported for the personal use of the individual who imports it, if the total quantity exported by the exporter during the calendar year in question does not exceed 10 kg; or

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: is exported for use in a laboratory for analysis, in scientific research or as a laboratory analytical standard, if the total quantity exported by the exporter during the calendar year in question does not exceed 10 kg.

Section.MarginalNote: Substances not subject to prior informed consent procedure
Section.Text: A person that has provided a notice of proposed export under subsection 101(1) of the Act may export a substance — other than a substance specified in Part 1 of the Export Control List — that is specified in Annex III of the Rotterdam Convention, but that is destined for use in a category other than the category specified for that substance in that Annex, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that person is a resident of Canada or, in the case of a corporation, has a place of business in Canada; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that person meets the requirements of sections 20 to 22.

Section.Text: If a person is required to export a substance specified in Part 1 of the Export Control List in compliance with a direction issued by the Minister under subparagraph 99(b)(iii) of the Act, that person must meet the requirements of sections 20 to 22 in addition to providing the notice of proposed export required under subsection 101(1) of the Act.

Subsection.Text: Subject to section 9, any person proposing to export any of the following substances must hold an export permit:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a substance that is specified in Part 2 or 3 of the Export Control List and Annex III of the Rotterdam Convention and that is destined for use in the category specified for that substance in that Annex;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a substance that is specified in Part 1 of the Export Control List whether or not it is specified in Annex III of the Rotterdam Convention; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a substance that is specified in Part 3 of the Export Control List and that is not specified in Annex III of the Rotterdam Convention.

Subsection.Text: Any person referred to in subsection (1) that has provided the Minister with a notice of proposed export under subsection 101(1) of the Act must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be a resident of Canada or, in the case of a corporation, have a place of business in Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: meet the requirements of sections 20 to 22; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: include a copy of the export permit with each shipment of the substance.

Subsection.Text: The application for an export permit must include the information listed in Schedule 2 and be accompanied by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a written undertaking dated and signed by the exporter, or by their duly authorized representative, stating that the exporter assumes full responsibility for the removal of the substance from the country of destination and any related costs, including the transportation, care, control and storage of the substance, in the event that the exporter exports the substance in contravention of any conditions set out in the export permit or if the export takes place after the export permit has expired or been cancelled;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case referred to in subparagraph 12(1)(c)(iii), documentation confirming that the substance has been used in or imported into the country of destination in the last 10 years;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case referred to in subparagraph 12(1)(c)(iv), the written consent of the designated national authority of the country of destination to the import of the substance; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a certification dated and signed by the exporter, or by their duly authorized representative, stating that the information provided in the application is accurate and complete.

Subsection.Text: The application and the documents referred to in subsection (1) may be submitted either in writing or in an electronic format that is compatible with the one that is used by the Minister.

If the notice of proposed export and the application for an export permit in relation to a particular substance are provided to the Minister at the same time, the exporter does not need to provide the information referred to in items 1, 2 and 4 to 8 of Schedule 2 if that information is provided in the notice.

Section.MarginalNote: Substances subject to prior informed consent procedure

Subsection.Text: Subject to section 16, in the case of the export of a substance subject to the prior informed consent procedure that is specified in Part 1 of the Export Control List and destined for destruction or a substance subject to the prior informed consent procedure that is specified in Part 2 or 3 of the Export Control List, the Minister must issue an export permit if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the permit application is received before the Rotterdam Secretariat has first informed the Rotterdam Parties through the PIC Circular of the country of destination’s response with respect to the import of the substance or of its failure to transmit that response;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the permit application is received after the Rotterdam Secretariat has first informed the Rotterdam Parties through the PIC Circular that the country of destination has given consent to the import of the substance; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the permit application is received after the Rotterdam Secretariat has first informed the Rotterdam Parties through the PIC Circular that the country of destination has failed to transmit a response with respect to the import of the substance and

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the permit application is received before the end of the six-month period that begins on the date of publication of that PIC Circular,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the permit application is received after the end of the 18-month period that begins on the date of publication of that PIC Circular,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: no regulatory action has been taken by the country of destination to prohibit the use of the substance and the substance has been used in or imported into the country of destination in the last 10 years, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the designated national authority of the country of destination has given written consent to the import of the substance.

Subsection.Text: An export permit issued under subsection (1) must specify the conditions of import imposed by the country of destination as set out in the PIC Circular or as may be specified in the designated national authority’s written consent, if applicable.

Section.MarginalNote: Other substances — Part 1 of Export Control List
Section.Text: Subject to section 16, in the case of an export for destruction of a substance — other than a substance subject to the prior informed consent procedure — specified in Part 1 of the Export Control List, the Minister must issue an export permit on receipt of the permit application.

Section.MarginalNote: Other substances — Part 3 of Export Control List
Section.Text: Subject to section 16, the Minister must, on receipt of a permit application, issue an export permit for the export of a substance specified in Part 3 of the Export Control List that is not specified in Annex III of the Rotterdam Convention.
An export permit expires at the end of the calendar year for which it is issued.
The Minister must refuse to issue an export permit if the Minister believes on reasonable grounds that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the exporter is not able to export the substance in compliance with the Act, these Regulations or the conditions imposed by the country of destination;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the export would contravene the Act, any regulations made under the Act or any other measure taken under the Act; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the exporter provided false or misleading information in the notice of proposed export, in the permit application or in any document provided under paragraph 11(1)(b) or (c).

Heading.TitleText: Cancellation, Amendment or Suspension of Permit

Subsection.Text: If the Rotterdam Secretariat advises the Rotterdam Parties through the PIC Circular that a country of destination does not consent to the import of a substance for which an export permit has been issued, the Minister must cancel the permit and the cancellation takes effect on the day that is six months after the date of publication of that PIC Circular.

If a designated national authority advises the Minister that it revokes its written consent to the import of a substance for which an export permit has been issued, the Minister must cancel the permit and the cancellation takes effect on the day that is 30 days after the day on which the Minister is advised of the revocation.

If the Rotterdam Secretariat advises the Rotterdam Parties for the first time through the PIC Circular that a country of destination has failed to transmit a response with respect to the import of a substance for which an export permit has been issued under paragraph 12(1)(a) or subparagraph 12(1)(c)(i), the Minister must cancel the permit and the cancellation takes effect on the day that is six months after the date of publication of that PIC Circular.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Modification of conditions of import — PIC Circular
Subsection.Text: If the Rotterdam Secretariat advises the Rotterdam Parties through the PIC Circular that a country of destination has modified the conditions of import of a substance for which an export permit has been issued, the Minister must amend the permit in accordance with the new conditions and the amendment takes effect on the day that is six months after the date of publication of that PIC Circular.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Modification of conditions of import — designated national authority
Subsection.Text: If a designated national authority advises the Minister that it has modified the conditions of import of a substance for which an export permit has been issued, the Minister must amend the permit in accordance with the new conditions and the amendment takes effect 30 days after the day on which the Minister is advised of the modifications.

The Minister may cancel or amend an export permit under this section only if a notice giving reasons for the amendment or cancellation has been sent to the exporter by mail, electronic mail or facsimile.
The Minister must cancel an export permit if the Minister believes on reasonable grounds that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the exporter is not able to export the substance in compliance with the Act, these Regulations or the conditions set out in the export permit;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the export contravenes the Act, any regulations made under the Act or any other measure taken under the Act;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the exporter failed to comply with a condition set out in the export permit;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the exporter failed to comply with the undertaking provided under paragraph 11(1)(a); or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the exporter provided false or misleading information in the notice of proposed export, in the permit application or in any document provided under paragraph 11(1)(b) or (c).

Subsection.Text: The Minister must, before cancelling an export permit under this section, notify the exporter of the proposed cancellation by mail, electronic mail or facsimile.
The notice of proposed cancellation must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: indicate the reasons for the proposed cancellation;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: inform the exporter of the interim suspension of the permit; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: inform the exporter that it may make written representations concerning the proposed cancellation.

Subsection.Text: The export permit is suspended for the period beginning on the day on which the notice of the proposed cancellation is received and ending on the day on which the Minister makes a decision respecting the proposed cancellation.
The exporter may, within 15 days after the day on which the notice is received, make written representations concerning the proposed cancellation.
The notice of proposed cancellation is considered to have been received by the exporter

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on the day on which it is delivered, if it is delivered personally;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on the 10th day after the day on which it is postmarked, if it is sent by mail; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: on the date that is indicated by the sending apparatus, if it is sent by electronic mail or by facsimile.

Section.Text: An exporter must keep at the exporter’s principal place of business in Canada, for a period of five years after the end of the calendar year for which the export permit is issued,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the export permit;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the application for the export permit and the documents required under paragraphs 11(1)(a) to (d) if the originals were submitted to the Minister or, if copies were submitted to the Minister, the original of the application and documents;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: for each export of a substance, proof of liability insurance coverage as required under section 20;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: for each export of a substance, a copy of the label referred to in section 21 and the safety data sheet referred to in section 22; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any shipping documents or any other documents that substantiate the date of the export and the exact quantity of the substance that was exported.

Section.Text: The exporter must have liability insurance in an amount of not less than $5,000,000 for each export in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any damages arising from the export for which the exporter could become liable; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any costs that could be imposed on the exporter under the applicable laws for cleaning up the environment as a result of the substance being released into the environment during export.

Subsection.Text: An exporter must affix to any container in which a substance is exported a label that includes the following information in both official languages and, as far as practicable, at least one of the official languages of the country of destination:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the substance as it appears on the Export Control List and the commodity code of the substance as it is identified in the Harmonized Commodity Description and Coding System;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the hazards to the environment or human health that can arise from the nature of the substance or, if applicable, the product that contains it; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the precautionary measures to be followed when handling, using or being exposed to the substance or, if applicable, the product that contains it, and the first aid measures to be administered in case of exposure.

Subsection.Text: In the case of a bulk shipment, the exporter must either affix a label in accordance with subsection (1) or include with each shipment a label or a document that contains the information required to be included on the label.
For the purposes of subsection (2), bulk shipment means the shipment of a substance without any packaging or containment other than containment in

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a vessel having a water capacity of more than 454 L;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a freight container or a portable tank;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a road vehicle or a railway vehicle; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the hold of a ship.

Section.Text: The exporter must include with each export of the substance, in both official languages and, as far as practicable, at least one of the official languages of the country of destination, a safety data sheet as defined in section 2 of the Hazardous Products Act that meets the requirements of the Hazardous Products Regulations in respect of the substance or, if applicable, the product that contains it.

Heading.TitleText: Conditions Relative to the Minamata Convention

Section.Text: A person that has provided a notice of proposed export under subsection 101(1) of the Act may export a mixture that contains elemental mercury (CAS 7439-97-6) at a concentration of 95% or more by weight only if the mixture

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is, or is contained in, a hazardous waste or hazardous recyclable material regulated by the Export and Import of Hazardous Waste and Hazardous Recyclable Material Regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is exported for use in a laboratory for analysis, in scientific research or as a laboratory analytical standard, if the total quantity exported by the exporter during the calendar year in question does not exceed 10 kg; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is contained in a manufactured item that during manufacture is formed into a specific physical shape or design and has for its final use a function or functions wholly or partly dependent on its shape or design.

ScheduleFormHeading.Label: SCHEDULE 1
ScheduleFormHeading.TitleText: Information To Be Provided in Notice of Proposed Export

Section.Text: The name, civic and postal addresses, telephone number and, if any, fax number and email address, in Canada, of the person proposing to export a substance.
The name, title, civic and postal addresses, telephone number and, if any, fax number and email address of the duly authorized representative, if applicable.
For each substance exported, by country of destination,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the substance as it appears on the Export Control List;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the country of destination;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the expected date or dates of export;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the estimated quantity of the substance to be exported;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: an indication

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: that the export is for the purpose of destroying the substance, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: that the substance is intended for either industrial, pesticidal or another use;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: an indication of whether the substance is exported under the Export and Import of Hazardous Waste and Hazardous Recyclable Material Regulations, if applicable; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a substance specified in Part 2 or 3 of the Export Control List and also listed in Annex A or B of the Stockholm Convention,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: if the substance is exported under paragraph 6(2)(a) or (b), an indication of the specific exemption or acceptable purpose that applies to the substance,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: an indication of whether the substance is exported under paragraph 6(2)(c) and, if so, the name and civic address of the facility at which the disposal or recycling will take place and the method that will be used to dispose of or recycle the substance,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: an indication of whether the substance is exported for use in a laboratory for analysis, in scientific research or as a laboratory analytical standard,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: an indication of whether the substance is incidentally present in trace amounts in the product that is being exported, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: an indication of whether the substance is exported under paragraph 6(2)(f) and, if so, the date of manufacture of the product that is being exported.

ScheduleFormHeading.Label: SCHEDULE 2
ScheduleFormHeading.TitleText: Information To Be Provided in Application for Export Permit

Section.Text: The name, civic and postal addresses, telephone number and, if any, fax number and email address, in Canada, of the exporter.
The name, title, civic and postal addresses, telephone number and, if any, fax number and email address of the duly authorized representative, if applicable.
The name, civic and postal addresses, telephone number and, if any, fax number and email address of the importer.
The name of the substance as it appears on the Export Control List.
The expected date or dates of export.
The estimated quantity of the substance to be exported.
The country of destination.
An indication

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that the export is for the purpose of destroying the substance; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that the substance is intended for either industrial, pesticidal or another use.

Section.Text: The common name and trade name of the substance, if applicable.
The CAS registry number of the substance, if applicable.
The commodity code for the substance set out in the Harmonized Commodity Description and Coding System prepared by the World Customs Organization, as amended from time to time, if applicable.
If the substance is contained in a product,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the product; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the concentration of the substance in the product.

Section.Text: The following information respecting the export:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the customs office through which it is expected to be exported from Canada, if known;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the countries through which the substance will transit, if known; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the proposed number of exports for the calendar year, if known.

Section.Text: The safety data sheet for the substance or, if applicable, for the product that contains the substance.

Subsection.Text: In this section, former Regulations means the Export of Substances on the Export Control List Regulations as they read immediately before the day on which these Regulations come into force.

These Regulations do not apply to an exporter if the exporter exports a substance on or after the first day on which both sections 114 and 115 of the Economic Action Plan 2014 Act, No. 1 are in force, but before a day to be fixed by order of the Governor in Council for the purposes of sections 131, 134 and 136 of that Act, and if the exporter would not, were the former Regulations in force at the time, be in contravention of the former Regulations.
